definition:
A $d$-dimensional *cellular automaton* is a triple
$\Acal = \langle Q,\Neigh,f \rangle$ where:

1.  $Q$ is a nonempty set, called *alphabet* or *set of states*.
    \[it:ca-states\]

2.  [$\mathcal{N}$]{}= { \_1, …, \_[|[$\mathcal{N}$]{}|]{} }

    is a *finite, nonempty* subset of ${\ensuremath{\mathbb{Z}}}^d$,
    called *neighborhood index*. \[it:ca-neigh\]

3.  $f : Q^{\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}\to Q$ is the *local function*.
    \[it:ca-loc\]

The local function of the cellular automaton
${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$ induces, by synchronous application at all
points, a *global function* $F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$ on
$d$-dimensional *configurations*
$c : {\ensuremath{\mathbb{Z}}}^d \to Q$: $$\label{eq:ca-glob}
F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(c)(z)
= f \left( c(z+\nu_1), \ldots, c(z+\nu_{|{\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}|}) \right)
= f \left( {\left.{c}\right|_{z+{\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}}} \right) \;.$$
Observe that the global function is continuous in the product topology.

Cellular automata are a Turing-complete model of computation. In fact,
given a Turing machine, it is straightforward to construct a cellular
automaton that emulates it in real time. On the other hand, given a
one-dimensional cellular automaton, there exists a Turing machine that
emulates it in linear time with respect to the size of the input.

Given a one-head Turing machine
$T = \langle S, s,t,r, \Sigma, B, \delta \rangle,$ it is straightforward
to construct a one-dimensional cellular automaton
$\Acal_T = \langle Q, \Neigh, f \rangle$ that simulates $T$, by putting
$Q = S \times \Sigma \times \{0,1\},$ $\Neigh = \{-1,0,1\},$ and, for
$q_x = (s_x,\sigma_x,h_x)$, $f(q_{-1},q_0,q_1) = (s,\sigma,h)$ where:

-   $s$ is $\pi_S \circ \delta(s_0,\sigma_0)$ if $h_0=1$, and $s_0$
    otherwise.

-   $\sigma$ is $\pi_\Sigma \circ \delta(s_0,\sigma_0)$ if $h_0=1$, and
    $s_0$ otherwise.

-   $h$ is 1 if either $h_{-1}=1$ and
    $\pi_{L,R} \circ \delta(s_{-1},\sigma_{-1}) = R,$ or $h_{1}=1$ and
    $\pi_{L,R} \circ \delta(s_1,\sigma_1) = L;$ and 0 otherwise.

Then the $S$-component of $Q$ simulates the state alphabet of $T$, the
$\Sigma$-component of $Q$ simulates the input alphabet, and the
$\{0,1\}$-component simulates the read/write head.

Cellular automata make good tools for *qualitative analysis*. In fact,
given the description of a cellular automaton, it is straightforward to
write a computer program that implements its features. Also, several
phenomena in different fields of sciences — from physics to biology to
sociology — can be described in terms of finite-range interactions
between discrete agents.

On the other hand, retrieving the properties of the global dynamics from
the local description is usually a very difficult task, and may depend
on the dimension. As an example, reversibility of the global function is
decidable in dimension $1$ but not in dimension $2$ (or higher).

The definition above can be generalized to the case of a generic group
$G$ acting by *translations* on the space $Q^G$ of configurations. If
$$\label{eq:transl}
L_g(x) = g \cdot x \;\; \forall x \in G \;,$$ then the local function
$f : Q^{{\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}} \to Q$ (${\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}$
being a finite nonempty subset of $G$) induces
$F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}: Q^G \to Q^G$ via the relation
$$\label{eq:glob-gen}
F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(c)(g)
= f \left( {\left.{(c \circ L_g)}\right|_{{\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}}} \right)
= f \left( {\left.{c}\right|_{g{\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}}} \right)
\;\; \forall c : G \to Q\;.$$ Observe that $L = \{L_g\}_{g \in G}$ is a
*left* action, while $(c,g) \mapsto c \circ L_g$ is a *right* action. It
is of course possible to only use left action by defining
$F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(c)(g)$ as
$f \left( \restrict{(c \circ L_{g^{-1}})}{\Neigh} \right)$ instead:
since this is just a *reparametrization* of the family $L$, the bulk of
the theory does not change.
